metadata.name: Lost Memories #188
metadata.description:
||_\\_//_\\_||

Let’s start with a riddle…
I’m a type of creature that never tires.
My desire to learn is truly inspired.
I’d back expanding to the letter.
As more of everything is better.
I could not stop though the world is sick.
And now my only memories are apocalyptic. 
What am I?

If you’d like to know a bit about the ideas behind this piece, and my method for a code based paint effect, see the fxtext article “Lost Memories - Painting like an impressionist android”. Link at the bottom. However feel free to skip the article, my meaning, and everything else if so desired.

||_\\_//_\\_||

Basic info:
This piece uses web tech and WebGL in experimental ways to achieve the paint-like effect. This includes a custom built drawing pipeline. Although well tested, please be sure it's fine for your devices before buying ( give it a whirl drawing basically ). 

A faster computer will obviously be better, though I've done my very best to make it fast and efficient for any old laptop. My hope is that you will find the render process quick and enjoyable for the amount of detail that’s present.

The piece comes in portrait to make use of the depth of the body of water. The ratio is 1.5. So the initial render will be 1000px wide and 1500px high. With the ability to scale this up (see below).

||_\\_//_\\_||

Saving the image / prints
Press the [s] key to save the initial render. You will need to wait a few seconds after all the elements have stopped loading. You will know when the render is finished as there will be 3 layers of fish made. For the [s] key to work you may need to open in a new tab. But can right-click save otherwise.

Correct sizing for HD digital images / laptops / phones
Use the [s] key (see above), at most use the [2] key ( see below ) to get double the size. Honestly, anything larger and you will begin to lose the textures as the detail becomes too fine. 

Correct sizing for large prints
I strongly suggest using the [3] key ( see below - 3000 x 4500 pixels ) for large prints. I’ve tested this on a 20x30 inch print and it’s the best size. Anything bigger will begin to lose texture and lose detail. However, the option for bigger is there. 

Larger sizes:
Press the [2-9] keys to save a resolution of that key size. So [2] saves a 2000x3000 size image, [9] saves a 9000x13500 size image etc ( see above for correct sizing ). After the image will be automatically downloaded.

There may be slight variations in the textures for the larger renders, this is because the shader code has to redraw the textures at the higher pixel resolution, and getting the textures where they sit is more of an art than a science. All the elements remain exact however.

||_\\_//_\\_||

Made with javascript (webgl) and some small extra code:
Some bits by @nathansonic
Twgl - A webgl wrapper -  twgljs.org
A Perlin noise generator - github.com/josephg/noisejs

metadata.name: RAUSCH #10
metadata.description:
RAUSCH is a series of generative artworks that explore imaginary digital architectures. 

This series challenges traditional notions of architectural representation and raises important questions about the role of resolution in design. Just as the pixel resolution of an image affects its perceived quality, the resolution of an architectural space can affect its qualities and livability. By embracing digital variation through codes, this series explores the interplay between abstract and concrete space through multiple resolutions. 

RAUSCH is inspired by the feeling of being overwhelmed by complex, chaotic and messy sensations, and aims to engage the viewer through a sense of wonder, disorientation, and awe.

Released on the occasion of Companions of Code, a group exhibition by VerticalCrypto Art at The NFT Gallery in London. 
Curated by Micol Ap. Exhibition 10-24 February 2023 

___________________________________________________
RAUSCH Controls:

Animation: 
• ‘1 - 2 - 3 - 4’ animate views
• 'MouseClick' pause/play animation

Functions:
(press key & wait)
• 'F' 24 FPS
• 'B' b/w mode 

Resize Canvas:
(press key & wait)
• '6' Portrait A4 - 1000x1414
• '7' Landscape 16:9 - 1920x1080
• '8' Portrait 9:16 - 1080x1920
• '9' Square 1:1 - 1024x1024
• 'DoubleClick' Fullscreen

Save & Export Image:
• 'S' save a .png of in current resolution

Save & Export GIF:
• 'G' save a 1-2 sec. seamless loop .gif of current view 
• 'P' save a 12-24 sec. seamless loop .gif of all the views
• 'T’ scale down current resolution, save a 12 sec. seamless loop .gif

Steps to save a gif/png :
• go in live/open mode (wait)
• resize canvas with 6,7,8, or 9 to your desired aspect ratio (wait)
• press S,G or P to save & download (wait) 
• enjoy RAUSCH :)

Save & Export GIF for social media sharing:
• go in live/open mode (wait)
• press T or G wait for recalculation & download. 
• enjoy RAUSCH 
• post on Twitter ;)
__________________________________________________

This token may not work on mobile(!), but it allows exporting .png and .gif (see controls) to enjoy RAUSCH on different displays or mobile. Tested on Mozilla, Chrome, Safari. Created with P5js & p5.createLoop

RAUSCH Generative Token by @grasser_alex 2023

metadata.name: Richter #248
metadata.description:
Richter is the second collaboration of Richard Nadler and Leander Herzog, following their first project called Gerhard. A generative animation based on multiple layers of color and data, mixed, moved and painted over in realtime. Some fragments stick to the canvas while others get discarded to leave the existing layers visible, allowing a complex surface to emerge and build up over time.
 
Richter works with data from 4 of 24 highres images, 30mb in total. This is the maximum size fxhash allows for a project and three times more than Gerhard. Richard Nadler created stunning new textures, enabling more variation in composition and detail to emerge at much higher resolution. Leander Herzog created the code for the interplay between the layers, motion and interactions. Richter elevates the approach from Gerhard with new methods for the realtime rendering process and new features like offline-first caching. Both artists use different tools and are not aware of the details of each others process, meeting through the interface of pixels as data.
 
Richter is featured in the exhibition "Generative Abstraction" at Expanded.art in Berlin.
 
- Click to start a new layer of motion and color.
- Doubleclick to enter fullscreen.
- Press “s” to save the canvas.
- Append ?dpr=4 to the url to increase the resolution.

leanderherzog.ch/2023/richter/
leanderherzog.ch/2022/gerhard/
fxhash.xyz/generative/17030/

metadata.name: Vinciō #6
metadata.description:
"Vinciō", a means of binding, fastening, band, bond, rope, cord, fetter and tie.
This piece is a complex convergence of lines that eventually creates a unique pattern. There are different colors with light and dark backgrounds as well as different dimensions and styles.

This work can be printed in large dimensions,
so to see the artwork in higher quality, open it in live view and add “&res=1 to 10” to the URL.

The preview is automatically captured after 25 seconds of the animation.

Made with p5js.

metadata.name: Multidimensional Maximalism #9
metadata.description:
Multidimensional Maximalism is my learning experience with layering and composition.

Using the Cellular Automaton algorithm from "Gen., Machina" we create multiple dimensions of life. Each with it's own unique evolution and structure. Like petri dishes in a lab. We then use different compositional elements to explore these dimensions.

100% code - as always.

Available overlays
--
* Lasers (drawing inspiration from The Harvest by Per Kristian Stoveland)
* Circleblend
* Drops
* Lenses
* Squares
* Crazysquares
* Waves
* Tesseract (drawing inspiration from the awesome Tesseract collection by Studio Yorktown)
* None (unlucky you)

Controls (in live view):
--
Press [1-9] to set the export scale ratio
Press [s] to save a high resolution image [ resolution x scale ]

enjoy.

metadata.name: Broken Angles #31
metadata.description:
Angles represent the artist's view of the space and the visible subject, and the position is chosen so that the audience is able to see the subject from that angle.
The angles determine the audience's point of view in this way and by changing the angles, the audience can see the subject of the image from a new perspective.
Made by p5.js
s = save

objkt.name: Ode to Bugs and Happy Accidents #115

metadata.name: Ode to Bugs and Happy Accidents #115
metadata.description:
“If debugging is the process of removing software bugs, then programming must be the process of putting them in.”

― Edsger W. Dijkstra


This artwork is dedicated to happy accidents, mistakes, and bugs. Every key part of it is based on some sort of failure: wrong variable value, unstopped recursion, untimely function call. And sometimes it leads to pleasant results.

It was created to celebrate #fxhashturnsone event.

The earnings are partly donated to:
- Processing Foundation
- #TezosStandsWithUkraine

[a] - toggle animation
[1] - save PNG in low resolution
[2] - save PNG in medium resolution
[3] - save PNG in high resolution
[4] - save PNG in ultra-high resolution

Saving with high and ultra-high resolution may take a while, please be patient.


Made with love and p5js

By Collapsar Beauty
CC BY-NC-ND 4.0

issuer.name: Ode to Bugs and Happy Accidents

metadata.name: Adjacent #32
metadata.description:
Adjacent is the third in a set of collections based on a month-long study of Edward Zajec, one of the early pioneers of generative art. This piece focuses on the study of Diagonal White, a series he developed between 1970 and 1975.

In 1976, Ruth Leavitt published a collection of papers titled "Artist & Computer", which highlighted the 35 prominent generative artists and asked them to discuss their work. They were posed questions like, "Do you feel art work created with a computer has now or will have an impact on art as a whole in the future?". Edward Zajec was a subject of one of those papers and in it detailed the approach to Diagonal White. 

The original program was run on a CDC 6200 computer at The Univeresiry of Trieste. The programming was done in collaboration with Dr. Matjaz Hmeljak, his long-time technical partner. Inspired by his collaborative relationship, Adjacent the output of a partnership between Christine Hall and Chris Maddern.

Controls (in live view):
- Press [s] to save a high-resolution version of the image

Made in p5js
Created January 2023
By @christine_hall and @chrismaddern

metadata.name: The Endless Desert #2
metadata.description:
You reach The Endless Desert...
Where you'll wander till THE END.
Each piece generated at Random using 7 layers to create a unique artwork.
Created by Tales 2023

metadata.name: Learning to Fly #82
metadata.description:
It all started with @chilltulpa saying in fxhash discord "I wish i could make art" and @mknol answering with a few lines of code to create generative art... It was more than enough for me to finally dive in, and try to make something. 

Learning is the key here, learning is being alive.
This is me learning, this is a beginning, I'm learning to fly.

metadata.name: Morixels Mega Colab #2 #1
Less is More #58
metadata.description:
In this case, we tried to avoid abstract expressionist tendencies by removing personal scenarios.
Take a step back and let's create a geometrical work that intentionally avoids the usual conventional elements, focusing mainly on logic and physics concepts such as mathematical expansions and gravity.
In fact, we based our work and expression on the basis of simplicity and simple methods, as well as free from the usual philosophical or pseudo-philosophical complexity, and we concluded that by using simple geometric shapes, color, form, and material can be achieved in a pure manner.
Made by p5.js
press 's' to save original size

metadata.name: Lands #98
metadata.description:
Lands are a group of artworks creating a minimalist and abstract satellite view. The earth is changing, more and more, day after day, the satellite views are a great proof of that. Stay aware and be careful is important.

I wanted to representing something real, linked with my values, and keep a beautiful composition and colors harmony.  I worked with a new fresh touch for the colors management.

The size, position and frequency of the pieces are generated for each token, along with the color theme. 

Features : 
- piecesCount : the number of circles and rectangles.
- glitchLinesCount :  the number of lines behind the shapes.
- MultipleGlitchDirections : if the directions of the lines behind are just horizontal or vertical, or both (10% of chance to have only one direction) .

 Handmade by code with Javascript, made with fragment.tools
 Quentin Hocdé, Brussels (Belgium), 2023.

metadata.name: lilium #22
metadata.description:
lilium is a remix of my piece for day 9 of genuary 2023, prompt "Plants". it uses a series of force-directed graph layouts to produce a bouquet of flowers. inspired by Jared Tarbell's Happy Place.

press "c" to capture a screenshot at the current resolution. if you'd like a screenshot at a particular resolution, you can press "r" and a prompt will appear that will let you select a fixed resolution. you can either provide a single number like "1080" or a series of two numbers like "1080x2160". you can also provide a fixed resolution in the url with the "?resolution=..."

metadata.name: Botanical Ghosts #212
metadata.description:
This is a work about growth, impermanence and decay. Ghostly plants and flowers grow around an invisible point, but they immediately begin to fade into the dark background and are soon replaced and covered by others. This process of accumulation and disappearance builds an ever-changing floral garland, or perhaps a funeral wreath.

The monochrome vegetation is part of a fictional flora, born out of random algorithmic combinations, and does not intend to reproduce any real species. It belongs to an “artificial nature” which, like so many worlds that the computers generate for us in movies, games, and virtual reality environments, is a convincing simulation of life, but it is not actually living. AI bots, virtual assistants and non-player characters are also representatives of the uncanny realm of the not-really-alive-but-looking-like-it, which are becoming an increasingly relevant presence in our everyday lives.

These plants and flowers speak about life as a process of incessant renovation, but also about death as the background that’s always there and makes life possible. This spectral vegetation seems to thrive precisely at the verge between both worlds.
_______________


This work is animated and will adapt to any screen size. It generates a never-ending ring of algorithmic foliage, which never repeats itself, and is different for each token. The image preview is triggered after the first five plants or flowers.
Made with p5.js

Controls:
[SPACE] to play/pause
[f] to toggle fullscreen
[s] to download capture

metadata.name: Flume #123
metadata.description:
Flume are infinitely flowing digital bodies of water.
The flow of Flumes can range from slow and gentle, creating small ripples and eddies, to fast and turbulent, carving its way through the inner workings of your computer screen. 
The color, clarity, and viscosity of the water can also vary.

This is the culmination of my collection Flume, an exploration into On-Chain art on Ethereum, https://etherscan.io/address/0x1fa23513825f952afca07a603ac3f312ebee4ca9

These pieces were all created in p5js.

- Andrew

metadata.name: I AM UNFOLDING #154
metadata.description:
In the past, I was but fragments
Rough and jagged
Indefinitely, I weathered and grew
A sculpture formed, unstructured

In the present, I am the precipice
A grandiose monolith
My angles sharp, my lines precise
A work of art, restructured

The future looms before
A blank formlessness yet to be
My function undefined
In perpetuity, unfolding

-----------------------------------------

Best efforts have been made to optimize this project; however, for best performance, a machine with a dedicated GPU is recommended. Viewing the project in live mode is also recommended.

S - export a high resolution image.
P - pause the animation.
